Orland Police Department Patrol Officer Bryan Simpson

Background. Following an internal investigation, a Notice of Intent to Discipline was issued to City of 
Orland Police Department Patrol Officer Bryan Simpson (Simpson) on April 30, 2019.

email where he allegedly asked for a receipt, the email clearly indicates his desire to purchase an 
OPD badge, changing the "16" on the badge in the photo to "K-9".

Findings Following Appeal: City of Orland Personnel Rule 643
Orland Police Department Patrol Officer Bryan Simpson

Appeal Hearing: August 5, 2019

Background.
Background.

Following an internal investigation, a Notice of Intent to Discipline was issued to City of 
Orland Police Department Patrol Officer Bryan Simpson (Simpson) on April 30, 2019. A Skelly 
Hearing was scheduled before City Manager Peter Carr (Carr) and took place on. June 4, 2019. 
Present at that hearing were Simpson and his counsel, Richard Fisher.
Following an internal investigation, a Notice of Intent to Discipline was issued to City of
Orland Police Department Patrol Officer Bryan Simpson (Simpson) on April 30, 2019. A Skelly
Hearing was scheduled before City Manager Peter Carr (Carr) and took place on. June 4, 2019.
Present at that hearing were Simpson and his counsel, Richard Fisher.
Following the Skelly hearing, Can issued a Notice of Disciplinary Action on June 18,
Following the Skelly hearing, Can issued a Notice of Disciplinary Action on June 18,
2019, as follows:
2019, as follows:

Badge: Proposed 3-day suspension is sustained for making inaccurate and 
inconsistent statements when questioned by the Chief of Police and others.
Badge: Proposed 3-day suspension is sustained for making inaccurate and
inconsistent statements when questioned by the Chief of Police and others.

Text conversation: Proposed 3-day suspension is sustained not only for 
this stand-alone incident but also in recognition of progressive discipline 
warranted by previous incidents as documented in Simpson's personnel 
file in 2013, 2014 and 2015. These incidents indicate a pattern of 
inappropriate communication and insubordinate behavior to your superior 
officers.
Text conversation: Proposed 3-day suspension is sustained not only for
this stand-alone incident but also in recognition of progressive discipline
warranted by previous incidents as documented in Simpson's personnel
file in 2013, 2014 and 2015. These incidents indicate a pattern of
inappropriate communication and insubordinate behavior to your superior
officers.

K9 Drug Kit: Proposed Letter of Reprimand is retained. This LOR will be 
placed in your personnel file for failure to properly document the change 
in K9 drug training aids.
K9 Drug Kit: Proposed Letter of Reprimand is retained. This LOR will be
placed in your personnel file for failure to properly document the change
in K9 drug training aids.

Simpson timely appealed this Notice of Disciplinary Action to the Orland City Council 
pursuant to City of Orland Personnel Rule 6-7. An Orland City Council closed session for the 
purpose of hearing the appeal and deliberating thereon was duly noticed for Monday, August 5, 
2019 at 4:00 PM.

pursuant to City of Orland Personnel Rule 6-7. An Orland City Council closed session for the
purpose of hearing the appeal and deliberating thereon was duly noticed for Monday, August 5,

Orland Police Department Patrol Officer Bryan Simpson

On November 30, 2018, Sergeant Johnson interviewed Simpson with Mr. Fisher present.
On November 30, 2018, Sergeant Johnson interviewed Simpson with Mr. Fisher present.

Simpson stated that he emailed Tom to ask for a receipt and he could provide the receipt. 
Simpson stated that Tom's reply to his email was, "What?" Simpson denied any other 
conversations with Tom about a receipt or the badge (verbal, text, and email). On December 2, 
2018, Simpson forwarded Sergeant Johnson the email Simpson had sent to Tom on August 28, 
2018.
Simpson stated that he emailed Tom to ask for a receipt and he could provide the receipt.
Simpson stated that Tom's reply to his email was, "What?" Simpson denied any other

Simpson argued that his inconsistency about where he obtained the badge was due to
Simpson argued that his inconsistency about where he obtained the badge was due to

forgetting where it came from and his mind searching for an answer because he did not want to 
say, "I don't know." Simpson also said he was positive that he had purchased it from Tom, so 
that appears why he stuck with that story until he was pushed and pushed for a different answer.
forgetting where it came from and his mind searching for an answer because he did not want to
say, "I don't know." Simpson also said he was positive that he had purchased it from Tom, so
that appears why he stuck with that story until he was pushed and pushed for a different answer.

This would have been an acceptable explanation save for one significant problem: 
Simpson emailed Tom at Uniforms, Tuxedos and More on August 29, 2018 less 90 minutes after 
Chief Tolle asked him where the badge came from and before Chief Tolle asked him a second 
time. Officer Simpson later stated that he had asked Tom for a receipt, but when he provided the 
email where he allegedly asked for a receipt, the email clearly indicates his desire to purchase an 
OPD badge, changing the "16" on the badge in the photo to "K-9".
This would have been an acceptable explanation save for one significant problem:
Simpson emailed Tom at Uniforms, Tuxedos and More on August 29, 2018 less 90 minutes after
Chief Tolle asked him where the badge came from and before Chief Tolle asked him a second
time. Officer Simpson later stated that he had asked Tom for a receipt, but when he provided the
email where he allegedly asked for a receipt, the email clearly indicates his desire to purchase an
OPD badge, changing the "16" on the badge in the photo to "K-9".
The fact is that Simpson stated repeatedly that he believed he purchased the badge from
The fact is that Simpson stated repeatedly that he believed he purchased the badge from

Tom and had requested a receipt from Tom. However, Simpson never request a receipt from 
Tom. Instead, he asked Tom to purchase a badge. Each time Simpson stated that he asked Tom 
a receipt, Simpson knew that was false.
Tom and had requested a receipt from Tom. However, Simpson never request a receipt from
Tom. Instead, he asked Tom to purchase a badge. Each time Simpson stated that he asked Tom
a receipt, Simpson knew that was false.
As stated, there was no dispute as to these facts.
As stated, there was no dispute as to these facts.
As stated, the suspension is upheld, but reduced to two days.
As stated, the suspension is upheld, but reduced to two days.
